rev.comment: updated screenshots to ones of a newer versions
rev.diff:
Line 17: Line 17:
== History ==
== History ==
â
[[Image:Wordinwine.png|thumb|A screenshot of [[Microsoft Word]] 2003 running under Wine.]]
+
[[Image:Microsoft_Office_Word_2003_on_ubuntu.png|thumb|A screenshot of [[Microsoft Word]] 2003 running under wine.]]
Bob Amstadt (the initial project leader) and Eric Youngdale started the Wine project in 1993 as a way to run Windows applications on [[Linux]]. Inspired by [[Sun Microsystems]]' Public Windows Initiative and [[Wabi (software)|Wabi]] <ref>[http://groups.google.com/group/comp.windows.x.i386unix/browse_thread/thread/88fbd87c0ae2e48f/5003eb8ed33ae522] Wine project status Sep 29 1993, 4:27 pm</ref> (an attempt to get windows API fully reimplemented on the public domain, a project later shot down by Microsoft in 1996<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0CGN/is_1999_May_7/ai_54580586 Sun Uses ECMA as Path to ISO Java Standardization] (Computergram International, 7 May 1999)</ref>) for the [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] operating system, it originally targeted Windows 3.x ([[16-bit application|16-bit]]) [[application software]], although it [[as of 2007|currently]] focuses primarily on the dominant 32-bit applications. The project originated in discussions on [[Usenet]] in [news:comp.os.linux comp.os.linux] in June 1993.<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://groups.google.com/group/comp.os.linux.misc/msg/daa52d28ff44919f | title = WABI available on linux or not | accessdate = 2007-09-21 }}</ref> [[Alexandre Julliard]] has led the project since 1994.
Bob Amstadt (the initial project leader) and Eric Youngdale started the Wine project in 1993 as a way to run Windows applications on [[Linux]]. Inspired by [[Sun Microsystems]]' Public Windows Initiative and [[Wabi (software)|Wabi]] <ref>[http://groups.google.com/group/comp.windows.x.i386unix/browse_thread/thread/88fbd87c0ae2e48f/5003eb8ed33ae522] Wine project status Sep 29 1993, 4:27 pm</ref> (an attempt to get windows API fully reimplemented on the public domain, a project later shot down by Microsoft in 1996<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0CGN/is_1999_May_7/ai_54580586 Sun Uses ECMA as Path to ISO Java Standardization] (Computergram International, 7 May 1999)</ref>) for the [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]] operating system, it originally targeted Windows 3.x ([[16-bit application|16-bit]]) [[application software]], although it [[as of 2007|currently]] focuses primarily on the dominant 32-bit applications. The project originated in discussions on [[Usenet]] in [news:comp.os.linux comp.os.linux] in June 1993.<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://groups.google.com/group/comp.os.linux.misc/msg/daa52d28ff44919f | title = WABI available on linux or not | accessdate = 2007-09-21 }}</ref> [[Alexandre Julliard]] has led the project since 1994.
Line 32: Line 32:
== Functionality ==
== Functionality ==
â
[[Image:Winecfg v0.9.48 ubuntu7.1 en.png|right|220px|Screenshot of winecfg]]
+
[[Image:Wine_configuration_screenshot.png|right|220px|Screenshot of winecfg]]
As of mid-[[As of 2007|2007]], Wine runs some software with good stability and most software with minor issues. Most native Microsoft Windows DLLs necessary for the execution of 32-bit Windows binaries have compatible Wine counterparts. The developers of the [[Direct3D]] portions of Wine have continued to implement new features such as [[pixel shaders]] to increase game support.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://wiki.winehq.org/DirectX-Shaders | title = DirectX-Shaders-The official wine wiki }}</ref> Wine can also use native DLLs directly, thus increasing functionality, but then a license for Windows is needed unless the DLLs were distributed with the application itself.
As of mid-[[As of 2007|2007]], Wine runs some software with good stability and most software with minor issues. Most native Microsoft Windows DLLs necessary for the execution of 32-bit Windows binaries have compatible Wine counterparts. The developers of the [[Direct3D]] portions of Wine have continued to implement new features such as [[pixel shaders]] to increase game support.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://wiki.winehq.org/DirectX-Shaders | title = DirectX-Shaders-The official wine wiki }}</ref> Wine can also use native DLLs directly, thus increasing functionality, but then a license for Windows is needed unless the DLLs were distributed with the application itself.
